passages.text: 2H Liftoff Hindered by Bad Weather & Slow Consumer - Yet Mx Peers' Multiples More Than Discount It

We expect 2H25 volumes for LatAm Bottlers to improve and still bring high- single- digit to low- double- digit EBITDA growth in 2H for most peers despite a persistently challenging weather pattern in Mexico and Brazil and a still sluggish consumption environment in key regions. Moreover, we believe market expectations, especially for KOF but also AC, largely reflect what should be still sluggish 3Q. As we revise our estimates for the Mx Bottlers, we find valuation enticing having underperformed the Mexbol by \(21\% /5\%\) pp (KOF/AC) respectively YTD and trading on avg at a \(15\%\) discount to the broader Mx Consumer peers, which are likely exposed to similar demand side risks but with a less resilient pricing power (here) while remaining with a superior 5yr EPS CAGR. In the case of Andina, we see limited room for further re- rating, trading at a \(10\%\) premium vs Mx Peers with similar EPS CAGR while it has slightly outperformed its local trading index (IPSA). Compared to consensus, our EBITDA estimates for this and next year for KOF are \(2 / 3\%\) ahead vs BBG consensus but mostly in line for AC and Andina.

KOF (OW) - A slower Mexico recovery but a clear inflection point. We are cutting our EBITDA estimates for KOF by \(5 / 3\%\) for this and next year mainly on the back of volume growth in Mexico for 3Q that will grow only \(0.5\%\) considering weather conditions in key territories have remained unsupportive for most of 3Q on top of a still lagging consumer environment. Pricing should also be softer in 2H, as the company addresses additional market share recovery efforts and adjusts utilization levels on its increased capacity in Mexico. Furthermore, as per our recent conversation with the company (here), Brazil volumes recovery is taking longer than expected considering weather conditions in key territories too. Despite KOF's more conservative path on the 2H25 recovery, we see its current valuation as a good entry point, trading at an \(8\%\) discount to AC\* and \(17\%\) vs the broader Mx Consumer sector with an outlook for EBITDA and EPS CAGR at HSD for the next yrs, being at the high end of the Consumer pack with historical higher earnings visibility.

AC\* (OW) - Expect operational leverage to kick in with mild volume recovery. In Mexico, while weather should be more manageable vs 1H, we expect volumes in 3Q to be \(+3.0\% \mathrm{y} / \mathrm{y}\) (considering easy comps with \(- 3.7\% \mathrm{y} / \mathrm{y}\) in 3Q24), which leads to a \(- 1\%\) volume drop for FY25 but vs \(- 4.3\%\) in 1H25. Still, we continue to see FY25 margins in Mexico flat \(\mathrm{y} / \mathrm{y}\) , which embeds 50bps \(\mathrm{y} / \mathrm{y}\) acceleration in 2H25. In the US, we also expect a clear inflection point with volume at positive territory \((+0.8\% \mathrm{y} / \mathrm{y})\) following LSD drops in 1H, which underscores a still sluggish macro environment. With this and despite reductions in our EBITDA estimates of \(2\%\) for this and next year, we expect top- line growth to be at \(+7\%\) this year (in- line with guidance, here) and with stable EBITDA margin.

Andina (N) - Strong volume momentum to persist in 3Q. Valuations are already at a small premium. We expect Andina to deliver \(4\%\) volume expansion in Brazil and \(2\%\) in Chile. Argentina and Paraguay should also post volume expansion, but with Argentina now having tougher comps. This should also support margins in 3Q and 2H. We are keeping our 2025E EBITDA of
LatAm Food & Beverages and Agribusiness

CLP617bn stable, in line with consensus. We marginally reduce our 2026E figure by \(3\%\) to CLP656bn, \(2\%\) below consensus. We see Andina at \(13x\) PE 26E, which is a small premium to KOF, thus justifying our Neutral rating. Our Dec- 26 PT is slightly up to CLP4,600/share from CLP 4,400/share.

Coca-Cola FEMSA Local (Overweight; Price Target: Ps204.00)

We remain OW on KOF as we see solid operational despite a mild recovery in volume momentum in key region (Mx and Bz). We expect EBITDA and EPS CAGR (24- 29E) of \(7\%\) and \(9\%\) , respectively, which is among the strongest pace of growth within the Mexican consumer space. Valuation remains enticing trading at a high SD discount to AC\* and vs the Broader Mx Consumer sector. Additionally, we believe KOF should be well positioned to keep consolidating the Latin American market in the medium term.

Our Dec- 26 PT is based on 50/50 blend of a DCF and an EV/EBITDA sum of the parts. We attribute an 8.0x EV/EBITDA multiple for Mexico ops and a 6.5x for LatAm as we reflect normalizing risk- free rates. At our price target, KOF would be trading at \(\sim 14.4x\) 12m forward P/E and \(\sim 7.1x\) EV/EBITDA. Our ADR price target is derived by dividing our KOFUBL price target by by JPMc '25E MXN estimate of Ps19.5/USD, multiplied by the 10:1 share/ADR ratio.

Arca Continental (Overweight; Price Target: Ps230.00)

We rate AC\* as OW considering its strong growth prospects and strategic positioning in the market. Our estimates incorporate an EBITDA CAGR of \(7.0\%\) , and EPS CAGR of \(10.0\%\) . Furthermore, management has strong credibility regarding strategic initiatives in pricing, efficiency, and expense control, which are expected to drive margins to new highs in key geographies. Additionally, Arca's ability to maintain resilient volume dynamics and implement pricing strategies should allow it to sustain strong margins, even in a challenging economic environment.
Our Dec- 26 price target is based on a 50/50 approach utilizing a 14x target P/E multiple on 26e EPS and a 10yr DCF.
Table 4:AC-Change in estimates

Embotelladora Andina Local B (Neutral; Price Target: Ch\$4,600.00)

We have a positive view on LatAm bottlers given their consistent growth opportunities (improving consumption per capita, health & wellness and low sugary drinks, seltzers, energy drinks, flavors), as well as the ability of the sector to keep margins stable (via pricing, mix and cost controls). With that, we think the sector's valuation should be well sustained, delivering a good combination of growth and value. Nonetheless, we rate Andina Neutral as the least preferred option in the sector currently, due to lower average growth than peers (- 6% 5Y EPS CAGR vs peers near 10%). The company trades at a small premium to peers.

Our Dec- 26 PT is based on a 50/50 combination of a 10Y DCF and a 2026E based EV/EBITDA SOTP analysis. For the DCF analysis, we use a WACC of 11.2%, with a country risk of 3.5%. In our SOTP analysis, we assume 8.0x EV/EBITDA for Chile, which we think is a conservative assumption given premium margins and high capillarity. We assume 7.5x for Brazil on stronger growth and improving margins, and 7.0x for Paraguay, given its resilience. For Argentina we assume 6.5x EV/EBITDA, which we think is a fair multiple considering pace of recovery.

The chart(s) show J.P. Morgan's continuing coverage of the stocks; the current analysts may or may not have covered it over the entire period. J.P. Morgan ratings or designations: OW = Overweight, N= Neutral, UW = Underweight, NR = Not Rated

J.P. Morgan uses the following rating system: Overweight (over the duration of the price target indicated in this report, we expect this stock will outperform the average total return of the stocks in the Research Analyst's, or the Research Analyst's team's, coverage universe); Neutral (over the duration of the price target indicated in this report, we expect this stock will perform in line with the average total return of the stocks in the Research Analyst's, or the Research Analyst's team's, coverage universe); and Underweight (over the duration of the price target indicated in this report, we expect this stock will underperform the average total return of the stocks in the Research Analyst's, or the Research Analyst's team's, coverage universe. NR is Not Rated. In this case, J.P. Morgan has removed the rating and, if applicable, the price target, for this stock because of either a lack of a sufficient fundamental basis or for legal, regulatory or policy reasons. The previous rating and, if applicable, the price target, no longer should be relied upon. An NR designation is not a recommendation or a rating. In Americas equity research, some stocks under coverage have a rating but no price target; in these cases, we expect the stock will outperform/perform in line/underperform the average total return of the stocks in the Research Analyst's, or the Research Analyst's team's, coverage universe over the next six to 12 months. In our Asia (ex-Australia and ex-India) and U.K. small- and mid-cap Equity Research, each stock's expected total return is compared to the expected total return of a benchmark country market index, not to those Research Analysts' coverage universe. If it does not appear in the Important Disclosures section of this report, the certifying Research Analyst's coverage universe can be found on J.P. Morgan's Research website, https://www.jpmorganmarkets.com.
